# Preface {.unnumbered}

This is the script for the lecture "Advanced Statistical Methods and Optimization" at the DIT/Campus Cham.
I do realize, that this body of knowledge has been repeated over and over, but have decided to do my own nonetheless so I can add my own flavor to the realms of statistics.
This work is heavily inspired by [@r_wickhamgrolemund_2016].
Please note that this material is copyrighted, you are not allowed to copy, at least ask for permission - you are likely to get it.

Tim Weber, Oct. 2024

## Symbol Abbreviations {.unnumbered .unlisted}

[$\alpha$]{#sign-level}

:   significance level

[$\beta$]{#beta-risk}

:   false negative risk

[$\epsilon$]{#epsilon}

:   residuals

[$\mu_0$]{#truemean-gloss}

:   the true mean of a population

[$\varphi(x)$]{#pdf-gloss}

:   probability density function

[$\phi(x)$]{#cdf-gloss}

:   cumulative probability density function or cumulative distribution function

[$\sigma_0^2$]{#truevariance-gloss}

:   the true variance of a population

[$\sigma_0$]{#truesd-gloss}

:   the true standard deviation of a population

[$C_g$]{#Cg}

:   potential Measurement System Capability Index

[$C_{gk}$]{#Cgk}

:   Measurement Capability Index with systematic error

[$C_p$]{#Cp}

:   potential process capability as caluclated by \eqref{CpCalc}

[$C_{pk}$]{#Cpk}

:   actual process capability including centering as calculated by \eqref{CpkCalc}

[$k$]{#numpred}

: number of predictors in a model

[$MSE$]{#mse}

: mean squared errors as calculated by \eqref{mse}

[$n$]{#n-gloss}

:   number of datapoints/observations

[$P$]{#probabilities}

:   Probabilities

[$r^2$]{#r2}

: Coefficient of determination \eqref{r2}

[$r^2_{adjusted}$]{#r2adj}

: adjusted Coefficient of determination \eqref{r2adj}

[$sd$]{#sd-gloss}

:   the standard deviation of a dataset as computed via \eqref{sd}

[$SSE$]{#sse}

: Sum of squared errors as calculated by \eqref{sse}

[$x_i$]{#xi-gloss}

:   the individual datapoints

[$\bar{x}$]{#mean-gloss}

:   the mean value of the dataset as computed via \eqref{mean}

[$X$]{#X}

: Predictor Variable

[$Y$]{#Y}

: Response Variable

[$\hat{y}$]{#yhat}

: predicted value

[$y_i$]{#yi}

: true value
